attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a physical stock take of raw materials and finished product on 8th February 2025 to determine whether the stocks movement at the Branch was well managed and to assess the effectiveness of existing controls.
  • The findings were as shown below:
    • Polybags had a variance of +1,309 Pieces(exc. Akiyda used for FOC only)
    • Finished product had a variance of -229 Loaves for bread produced by the branch.
    • Yeast had a variance of +31.756 Pcs
    • White flour had a variance of +37.457 Kgs and
    • White Ingredient had a variance of +0.756 Pcs as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management  to implement adequate stock controls and improve checks on production materials’ usage.
attributes.effect: • The variances noted imply weak stock controls and lapses in monitoring raw materials’ usage at the branch.
attributes.remediation_plan: The branch management to strengthen controls in place to alleviate variances.

value:
• Deduction for 136 loaves was raised and the remaining difference of 93 will be absorbed by the excess flour of 37Kgs noted.
  • We will follow up on recording of yield in mixing chart to alleviate such instances in future.
  • We had instances of remixes, there is a possibility that yeast was skipped in the premixes but we will follow up with the supervisors and put measures in place to prevent this scenario.

•  We have recovered the shortfall in loaves and we will be following up to ensure accurate recording of yield as per BOM requirements in the mixing chart
  • For the polybags, we are implementing measures by separating polybags for market damages from production damages polybags so as to ensure accurate goods issue quantities for polybags damaged from production area

In the prior audit report dated 6th January 2025 stock were as seen below:

  • Polybags +750 pieces
  • Finished product -122.50
  • White Flour +19.83 Kgs
  • White Ingredient +1.42
• The variances noted imply weak stock controls and lapses in monitoring raw materials’ usage at the branch.

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a spot check on the weights of packed bread on 10th February 2025 to verify if the set bread weight standards were being adhered to.
  • Major underweights were noted in 800g CTW (31/45) which represented 69% of the sample taken as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to increase spot checks in the production area to ensure adherence to the required weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect: • Presence of underweight bread signified lapses in implementation of the set dough weights and also failure to monitor production process flow.

value: • I will do samples for the 800g variety to determine if there is any issues with the variety and follow up to prevent/minimize future underweights.
• Instances of overcooling might have contributed to this variety's underweights, but I will conduct my spot checks to review the matter.
•  In the previous audit report, Packed bread underweights were noted as follows; 400g - 45%, 600g - 10%, and 800g - 10%.

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis was done on the bread damage levels for both production and market based deformities for the period 20th January-8th February 2025 to detect if damage levels were within the set limits.
  • We noted the following:
    • Production damages  were 0.25% of the total production which was above the set standard of 0.2% and had a cost implication of KES 9,531.72
    • Market damages were 0.32% of the total sales which was within the 0.5% allowed limit 
  • We also conducted a verification of damage balances sent to ingredients to assess whether all the declared damages were physically available or sent to ingredients as per procedure.
  • We noted that for the period 20th January to 7th February 2025, damages  had a variance of  +56.50 Kgs Equivalent to excess 141.25 loaves.
attributes.recommendation:
• Enhance controls and spot checks within the production process.
  • Branch management to implement strong controls for damages balance movement.
attributes.effect:
• The production damages exceeded the set damage limits implying lapses in monitoring production process flow.
  • The excess damages sent to ingredients implied gaps in the monitoring of damages balance movement.

value:
• We will work to improve on production damages.
  • The excess damages arose from an issue we found where damaged bread was being added to market damages already broken down and we had recovered the same from supervisors. Going forward, we have put measures in place whereby the damages are reweighed twice and this has minimized the case of excess damages sent to ingredients as at now.

• We will put measures in place to minimize production damage levels. There is improvement from previous periods and we are working to improve further.
  • The excess damages arose from an issue we found where damaged bread was being added to market damages already broken down and we had recovered the same from supervisors. Going forward, we have put measures in place whereby the damages are reweighed twice and this has minimized the case of excess damages sent to ingredients as at now.

• During the prior audit dated 6th January 2025, it was noted that production damages were 0.37% of the total production while market damages were 0.38% of the total sales.
  • During the prior audit it was also noted that damages sent to ingredients had a negligible variance of -203.38 Kgs equivalent to 508.45 loaves.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing chart and mixing chart summaries for the period 20th January to 8th February 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • We noted the following:
    • Average yield was 193.17 loaves per bag
    • Average production was 93.10 bags equivalent to 95% of the set target of 98 bags.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    • 1,518 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to minimize remix cases by adhering to the set procedures.
attributes.effect:
•  The high number of remixes imply lapses in following the set procedures in the production process.
  • The yield and target achievement was okay for the reviewed period.

value: • The remixes noted were caused by Oven deck breakdown, Power outages and proofer machine breakdown experienced during this period.
• The remixes noted were caused by Oven deck breakdown, Power outages and proofer machine breakdown experienced during this period.

·       During the prior audit, the following were noted :

  •   Average yield  193.02

  •   Average production 92 bags.
Controls were adequate but not fully effected as seen in the remix cases.

attributes.title: Minishop Spot Check
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A spot check on Mini shop was done on 8th February 2025 to determine if all loaded bread was accounted for and if the sales were equivalent to the cash balances available since the mini-shop was cash-based.
  • We noted that all the sales done as at the time of the spot check were accounted for and all the expected bread balances from loading done exclusive of sales were physically available as illustrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The management should maintain the Mini shop controls.
attributes.effect: • The Mini shop was well controlled.

value: • In the previous audit dated 6th January 2025, Mini-shop had a variance of -59 arising from recording error of a prepayment done.

attributes.title: Debtors' Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis of the debt balances as at C.O.B 10/02/2025 (Exclusive of Institutions) was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.
  • The findings were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: •  Follow up on pending balances for clearance.
attributes.effect: • Debt balances were minimal, therefore well controlled, however efforts should be made to recover the pending balance.

value: • We are following up with sales representative.
• We will Follow up with sales rep, all customers (exc. Institutions) are cash based therefore this should be cleared.
• The previous audit noted that all customers had nil balance except for Institutions with a balance of KES 414,683.89.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We reviewed the branch’s production efficiency rate versus the Company’s set standards for the period 20th January to 8th February 2025 to ascertain if there were any major variations.
  •    We noted that the average production efficiency was at 3.96 bags per production worker which was below the set standard of 4.3.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • Branch management to introduce controls to ensure optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect: • The branch did not attain the set target implying extra cost of KES 38,031 for over-allocation of 35 extra workers to the production section.

value: • We are in the process of implementing some strategies to improve the production efficiency.

• We will follow up on the production efficiency after implementing the strategies we have come up with.
  • The manager has been advised to do close monitoring of production shift-wise and allocate the necessary manpower to ensure achievement of efficiency.
• The previous audit report dated 6th January 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 3.87 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  • We noted that, for the period 20th January to 8th February 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 93.75 crates which was below the standard set as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to ensure optimal allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch did not attain the set slicing efficiency implying extra cost of KES 7,296 incurred in paying excess 8 workers.

value: • We will monitor the flow in the packing area and sensitize employees to increase speed to attain the required target.
• We will follow up on shift-wise allocation of packers based on production.
• The previous audit report dated 6th January 2025 indicated a packing efficiency of 91.13 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st -9th February 2025.
  • We noted that all route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard as detailed in Appendix I below:
attributes.recommendation: • Maintain and enhance the fuel management controls within the branch.
attributes.effect: • All route vehicles’ fuel consumption was well controlled.

value:
• During the previous audit, it was noted that all vehicles’ mileage was well controlled.
  • A faulty speedometer was noted in KTWC 327Y.
